articles.headline: In Curbing Pay, Obama Seeks to Alter Corporate Culture
articles.snippet: In announcing executive pay limits, President Obama is trying to hold the financial industry accountable to taxpayers while aiming to change an entrenched corporate culture.
articles.abstract: In announcing executive pay limits, President Obama is trying to hold the financial industry accountable to taxpayers while aiming to change an entrenched corporate culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In announcing executive pay limits on Wednesday, President Obama is trying to hold the financial industry accountable to taxpayers while aiming to change an entrenched corporate culture that endorses outsize bonuses and perks that often bear little relationship to corporate performance.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Uncovering Lost Path of the Most Wanted Nazi
articles.snippet: Aribert Ferdinand Heim, wanted for medical atrocities at concentration camps, lived in Cairo until his death in 1992. His hiding place was unknown until now.
articles.abstract: Aribert Ferdinand Heim, wanted for medical atrocities at concentration camps, lived in Cairo until his death in 1992. His hiding place was unknown until now.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Even in old age the imposingly tall, athletic German known to locals as Tarek Hussein Farid maintained the discipline to walk some 15 miles each day through the busy streets of Egypt’s capital. He walked to the world-renowned Al Azhar mosque here, where he converted to Islam, and to the ornate J. Groppi Cafe downtown, where he ordered the chocolate cakes he sent to friends and bought the bonbons he gave to their children, who called him Uncle Tarek.
articles.byline: By Souad Mekhennet and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: At Madoff Hearing, Lawmakers Lay Into S.E.C.
articles.snippet: Regulators could not cool the Congressional fury on Wednesday over their failure to act on tips that might have exposed the Madoff scandal almost a decade ago.
articles.abstract: Regulators could not cool the Congressional fury on Wednesday over their failure to act on tips that might have exposed the Madoff scandal almost a decade ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Securities regulators could not cool the white-hot Congressional fury on Wednesday over their failure to act on tips that might have exposed the Madoff scandal almost a decade ago.

articles.headline: Video Chats Overcome Clunkiness
articles.snippet: Video phone calls aren’t dead, exactly, but Skype’s new program may revive interest in them.
articles.abstract: Video phone calls aren’t dead, exactly, but Skype’s new program may revive interest in them.
articles.lead_paragraph: When AT&T demonstrated its video telephone at the 1964 World’s Fair, everyone  including AT&T  pretty much figured that it would be the future. People wouldn’t just hear each other over the phone  they would see each other, too.

articles.headline: Foreign Firms Lining Up for Piece of Stimulus
articles.snippet: Despite the chatter about trade protectionism, foreign businesses are gearing up to win a piece of the package.
articles.abstract: Despite the chatter about trade protectionism, foreign businesses are gearing up to win a piece of the package.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  What makes a product American?
articles.byline: By Martin Fackler and James Kanter

articles.headline: Wall St. Pay Is Cyclical. Guess Where We Are Now.
articles.snippet: With tighter regulations, the pay for top bankers could align with pay for professions like doctors and lawyers.
articles.abstract: With tighter regulations, the pay for top bankers could align with pay for professions like doctors and lawyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: To most people, a salary cap of $500,000 would be anything but punishment.

articles.headline: Digital Pirates Winning Battle With Studios
articles.snippet: Widely available broadband access and new streaming sites have made it easy to watch pirated video online.
articles.abstract: Widely available broadband access and new streaming sites have made it easy to watch pirated video online.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the day last July when “The Dark Knight” arrived in theaters, Warner Brothers was ready with an ambitious antipiracy campaign that involved months of planning and steps to monitor each physical copy of the film.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Scrutiny of Bankers’ Perks Will Grow, Too
articles.snippet: In addition to salary caps for some banks receiving aid, President Obama called for a review of executive perks.
articles.abstract: In addition to salary caps for some banks receiving aid, President Obama called for a review of executive perks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Country club dues, gym memberships and personal assistants. Home security systems, chauffeur service and parking. And, of course, all those private jets to ensure the comfort and safety of the boss.

articles.headline: Science Found Wanting in Nation’s Crime Labs
articles.snippet: Forensic evidence is often the product of shoddy scientific practices that should be upgraded, a draft report found.
articles.abstract: Forensic evidence is often the product of shoddy scientific practices that should be upgraded, a draft report found.
articles.lead_paragraph: Forensic evidence that has helped convict thousands of defendants for nearly a century is often the product of shoddy scientific practices that should be upgraded and standardized, according to accounts of a draft report by the nation’s pre-eminent scientific research group.

articles.headline: Stimulus Talks Set to Continue After Centrists Push Cuts
articles.snippet: Democratic leaders said they would await the outcome of backroom bipartisan negotiation before holding a vote.
articles.abstract: Democratic leaders said they would await the outcome of backroom bipartisan negotiation before holding a vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senators worked furiously in backroom negotiations on Thursday to cut the cost of the more than $920 billion economic stimulus plan. Senate Democratic leaders said they would await the outcome of those talks before calling for a final vote on the measure, perhaps on Friday.
